ARABIC: إِذْ عُرِضَ عَلَيْهِ بِٱلْعَشِىِّ ٱلصَّٰفِنَٰتُ ٱلْجِيَادُ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: When swift horses, champing at the bit, were displayed before him in the afternoon,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: When they brought fleet-footed chargers in the evening to show him,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: And when one evening well-trained and running horses of noble breed were brought to him
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: When the noble galloping horses were displayed to him one evening,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: When fast footed steeds were presented to him at evening.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: When there were displayed before him, in the afternoon, well trained horses of the highest breed.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: When there were brought to him in the evening (horses) still when standing, swift when running--
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: When in the evening were presented to him the standing steeds,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: When there were shown to him at eventide lightfooted coursers
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: When well-bred horses, which were fleet of foot were paraded before him near the close of day,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: Recall what time there were presented Unto him, at eventide, s coursers swift-footed.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: One evening when there were displayed before him prancing steeds,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: Behold, there were brought before him, at eventide coursers of the highest breeding, and swift of foot;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: When there were displayed before him, in the afternoon, well trained horses of the highest breed [for Jihad (holy fighting in Allah's Cause)].
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: When his dressage steeds were presented to him in the evening,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: When the beautiful horses were paraded before him in the evening.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: [Mention] when there were exhibited before him in the afternoon the poised [standing] racehorses.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [38:31] When one evening — which is the period after midday — there were displayed before him the prancing steeds (al-sāfināt, ‘horses’, is the plural of sāfina, which denotes [a horse] standing on three legs with the fourth supported on the edge of the hoof, and derives from [the verb] safana, yasfinu sufūnan; al-jiyād is the plural of jawād, which is a ‘racer’; the meaning is that these [horses] are such that when they are halted they stand still and when they run they surpass [others] in speed). One thousand horses were displayed before him after he had performed the midday prayer, for he had wanted to use them in a holy struggle (jihād) against an enemy. But when the display reached the nine-hundredth [horse], the sun set and he had not performed the afternoon prayer. So he was greatly distressed.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: 523 (When there were shown to him at eventide) after the Zuhr (light footed coursers) pure, Arab horses.
